column13: In 2022, Z Energy released a Community and Sustainability Strategy 2030, with one of the goals to lead the transition Arahi Whanaketanga. By working with customers, suppliers, and partners to provide solutions, this goal will enable New Zealanders to join Z Energy on the path to a low-carbon future.
column20: Community and Sustainability Strategy, Transition leadership

column13: At Ampol, we strongly believe in the advantages of a diverse and inclusive workplace where individuals of varied backgrounds and perspectives are welcomed, encouraged and allowed to contribute to their full potential. Ours is a work environment where employees are valued for their distinctive experiences and the strength of their contribution. By diversity, we mean the prevalence of differences in our workplace, including thinking styles, capabilities, education and background, gender, ethnicity, religion, age, sexual orientation, disability, family status and all the other unique differences in our backgrounds that make each of us who we are.
column20: Diversity, Inclusion, Workplace inclusivity

column13: The Ampol Securities Trading Policy prohibits KMP from entering into any arrangements that would have the effect of limiting their exposure relating to Ampol securities, including vested Ampol securities or unvested entitlements to Ampol securities under the Ampol Equity Incentive Plan (AEIP). KMP prohibits entering into any margin lending arrangements or other secured financing arrangements concerning Ampol securities. KMP must undertake training to ensure they know and understand their obligations and responsibilities under the Ampol Securities Trading Policy, available on our website. A contravention is a serious matter and may lead to disciplinary action, including termination of employment.\t
column20: Securities Trading Policy, Remuneration policies, Training

column13: The Ampol Code of Conduct sets out the standards of conduct and behaviour we expect from you as an Ampol employee, wherever you work. It has been developed to help you and the people you work with to uphold the Ampol values.
column20: Code of Conduct, Standards of Conduct, Behaviour

column13: Ampol is committed to providing a psychologically and physically safe and healthy workplace for all its employees, contractors, and visitors and operating in a way that will not adversely affect the health and safety of its neighbours, the community, customers, or the public.
column20: Workplace safety, Healthy workplace, Health and safety

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: At Ampol, we expect high standards of integrity, honesty, openness and transparency. The Ampol values and the Ampol Code of Conduct embody these standards and guide our dealings and interactions inside and outside the business. So, if you suspect these standards and values are not being upheld, we encourage you to speak up.
column20: Integrity, Transparency, Standards

column13: Ampol is exempt from the climate-related disclosure requirements imposed under New Zealand law regarding its New Zealand business because its subsidiary, Z Energy, must prepare a group climate statement that includes information about Ampol's New Zealand business. Z Energy's climate statement will be published in April 2024 and available on the Z website afterwards.
column20: Climate-related disclosure, Exemption, Climate statement

column13: New Zealand's GenderTick is a formal accreditation program designed to acknowledge organisations that have successfully demonstrated their compliance and leadership in the gender equality space annually. In 2023, Z Energy achieved its reaccreditation for the fourth time through evaluation across critical indicators, including equal pay, leadership representation and a gender-inclusive culture. They have also now received the Advanced GenderTick for two consecutive years.
column20: Gender equality, GenderTick accreditation, Inclusive culture

column13: We support the Government's changes to the Safeguard Mechanism and understand the complexities of balancing the dual objectives of supporting a reliable and secure domestic fuel supply chain. We also deliver on Australia's international emission reduction commitments and support broader energy transition goals. We will continue to work with the Government as the reforms progress, recognising the impacts on Lytton refinery of manufacturing to the new fuel standards (from December 2025), as well as understanding how the use of renewable fuels may support other facilities covered under the Safeguard Mechanism to meet their own emissions reduction objectives.
column20: Government changes, Emission reduction commitments, Energy Transition

column8: A tiered approach to our Foodary offer
column13: We remain committed to our partnership with Woolworths and the Everyday Rewards program and offerings. This decision gave us greater flexibility to leverage our network and execute the next phase of our retail strategy. We are currently prioritising a tiered approach to our Foodary offer to cater to an evolving customer base, drive retail innovation, and ensure the proper retail format is reflected across the communities in which Ampol Foodary operates.
column20: Retail strategy, Customer base, Retail innovation

column13: As part of our retail strategy, we committed to an investment program to upgrade highway service centres along key Australian transport routes. The highway strategy is part of our mission to power better journeys, where all drivers and their passengers can refuel and re-energise in the comfort of modernised facilities.\t
column20: Highway service centres, Retail strategy, Modernised facilities

column13: With the rollout of AmpCharge EV chargers well underway, several other partnerships to offer 'at-destination' EV charging were established throughout 2023. Among the key partners were Mirvac, which will have AmpCharge chargers installed throughout its retail portfolio; the first AmpCharge Infrastructure will be installed outside our service station network.
column20: At-destination EV charging, Partnerships, Infrastructure

column7: Ampol does not currently report publicly.

We are committed to transparency, and our approach involves making sustainability integral to decision-making at all levels across our business. We do this in a way that balances environmental, social, and governance considerations within our broader strategic objectives. It is guided by the Ten Principles of the United Nations Global Compact (UNGC), of which Ampol is a signatory. Ampol is also a member of the UNGC Network Australia. We prepare our report concerning the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Standards to provide our stakeholders with comparable information on our sustainability performance.
Our People, Our Planet, Net Zero

column13: We recognise that this will take time, so we are committed to balancing the balance between investing in the core business, investing prudently in the energy transition and delivering shareholder returns. We are well placed to respond to changes in the pace of the transition with the ability to flex investment as proof points emerge.
column20: Energy transition, Shareholder returns, Flex investment

column13: Our approach to sustainability considers and aligns with recognised industry best practices and standards and ongoing feedback from our stakeholders on what they regard as material issues for Ampol to address. We are committed to continually developing and working to improve and implement policies and plans to drive progress on our commitments, with key policies and plans including the Climate Change Position Statement, Supplier Code of Conduct, Representation, Equity and Inclusion Policy, Human Rights Policy, and Reconciliation Action Plan.
column20: Sustainability, Best practices, Stakeholder feedback

column13: The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) seek to address the most significant challenges our world is facing today by 2030. We have identified ten SDGs within our sustainability strategy that we can contribute most as a Group.
column20: Sustainable Development Goals, Sustainability strategy, Group contribution

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: We were proud to launch a new 'card ecosystem' for AmpolCard. The launch included a streamlined AmpolCard platform, a mobile-compatible online portal, and new API management and data warehouse systems. This implementation took over four years and involved migrating approximately 11.2 million records.
column20: AmpolCard, Streamlined platform, API management

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Between 2019 and 2023, Z Energy delivered against a four-year strategy program that generated a new industry structure, a reconfigured liquid fuel supply chain and an optimised network and customer offer. That strategy was focused on optimising the core business, which resulted in a simpler and more efficient business while maintaining growth options from its privileged network of assets.\t
column20: Z Energy strategy, Liquid fuel supply chain, Optimised network

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Z Energy's investment in building its capability in digital technology and convenience retail is paying off. Their customers engage across a range of digital products aimed at providing convenience. Pay-by-plate technology is the ultimate speed and ease, while coffee pre-order remains a convenient option that our customers increasingly use.\t
column20: Digital technology, Convenience retail, Pay-by-plate technology

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Since the release of our Future Energy Strategy in May 2021, we have developed in-house modelling capabilities to estimate the impact of various climate change scenarios on the transport sector. By 31 December 2023, we have invested over AU$65 million in capital expenditure as part of our 2025 AU$100 million target in developing low-carbon transport solutions.
column20: Climate change scenarios, Low-carbon transport, Investment

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In 2023, we continued the execution of our Future Energy Strategy. Our Future Energy Strategy pursues the opportunities arising from the energy transition, focusing on initiatives targeting e-mobility, hydrogen, renewable fuels and other low-carbon products in Australia.
column20: Future Energy Strategy, E-mobility, Hydrogen, Renewable fuels

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In August, we partnered with a hydrogen equipment manufacturer and supplier, OneH2, to represent the United States-based company in the Australian hydrogen market. By partnering with OneH2, we aim to offer a unique and complete hydrogen refuelling solution, allowing customers to trial hydrogen technology and better understand how it can further assist their decarbonisation journeys through alternative fuel options.\t
column20: Hydrogen partnership, OneH2, Decarbonisation journeys

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans

column8: Co-founding Agreement with ARENA and NSW Government
column13: The live sites have been delivered with support from co-funding agreements with the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA) and the NSW Government. We also entered into an installation provider agreement with Energy Queensland's integrated energy solutions provider, Yurika, to initially deliver over 30 new EV charging bays.
column20: EV charging bays, Co-funding agreements, Installation provider

column13: The remaining capital expenditure is approximately $250 million, net of applicable federal government grants. The project is expected to be commissioned in the second half of 2025. Ampol also notes that, historically, gasoline cracks for the new specification (10ppm sulphur content) have traded at a premium to cracks for the current Australian grades.
column20: Capital expenditure, Gasoline cracks, Fuel standards

column8: Co-funded with The New Zealand Government, in conjunction with Air New Zealand
column13: The New Zealand Government, in conjunction with Air New Zealand, co-funded two feasibility studies to test the viability of establishing and operating a domestic Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) facility. In one of these studies, Z Energy is partnering directly with LanzaTech and LanzaJet, focusing on the potential to use forestry residue as a feedstock in producing SAF.
column20: SAF facility, Sustainable Aviation Fuel, Feasibility studies
